Question: Q1. How have you used forecasts (ecological, political, sports, any kind!) before in your day-to-day life?
Q2. How can ecological forecasts improve both natural resource management and ecological understanding?
Q3. How do you think forecasts of freshwater primary productivity will differ between warmer lakes and colder lakes?
Q4. Fill out information about your selected NEON site:
a. Name of selected site
b. Four letter site identifier
c. Latitude
d. Longitude
e. Lake area (km2)
f. Elevation (m)
Q5. Fill out the table with the description of site variables:
Air temperature
Surface water temperature
Nitrogen
Underwater PAR
Chlorophyll-a

Q6. Describe the effect of each of the following variables on chlorophyll-a. Chlorophyll-a is used as a proxy measurement for phytoplankton concentration and primary productivity in aquatic environments.
Air temperature
Surface water temperature
Nitrogen
Underwater PAR

Q7. Describe the relationship between each of these driving variables and productivity according to the ecosystem model we are using today (depicted above). For example, if the driving variable increases, will it cause productivity to increase (positive), decrease (negative), or have no effect (stay the same).
a. Surface water temperature
b. Incoming light
Q8. Classify the following as either a state variable or a parameter by dragging it into the corresponding bin. Once you have checked your answers, record the correct answers in the final report.

Q9. We are using chlorophyll-a as a proxy of aquatic primary productivity. In your final report, describe how you envision each parameter to affect chlorophyll-a concentrations. For example, if the parameter increases, will it cause productivity to increase (positive), decrease (negative), or have no effect (stay the same).
a. Maximum growth rate
b. Phytoplankton mortality rate
Q10. Describe the effect of changing phytoplankton initial conditions on your model run. As you increase or decrease initial conditions, how does this affect modeled primary productivity?
Q11. Describe the effect of changing the phytoplankton mortality parameter on your model run. As you increase or decrease mortality, how does this affect modeled primary productivity?

Q15. What is forecast uncertainty? How is forecast uncertainty quantified?
Q16. Inspect the weather forecast data for the site you have chosen:
a. How does increasing the number of ensemble members in the weather forecast affect your impression of the uncertainty in future weather?

c. Use the 'Save plot' button to save the NOAA forecast plot and copy-paste it into your final report.

Q17. Explain, in your own words, why it is necessary to convert the NOAA forecasts of air temperature and shortwave radiation into forecasts of water temperature and underwater PAR as a step towards generating forecasts of primary productivity.

Then, adjust the number of ensemble members to 30 and re-run the forecast. How does including driver uncertainty affect the forecast?
b. How does altering the initial condition of your forecast affect forecast output?
